reading

i just started a new novel by a young author about being a queer young millennial attempting to live and love. honestly, i don‚Äôt know why i haven‚Äôt learned my lesson with these books yet. i keep picking them up in the hopes that this book will finally be the one to move me, make me think about the meaning of relation, make me love the characters, even though i know i‚Äôm going to end up disappointed and pissed off. and once again, i am disappointed and pissed off! why are all these books that purport to be about ‚Äúflawed people learning to love each other‚Äù actually about people who are incredibly cruel to each other and who are totally uninvested in trying to be a good or kind person?

i‚Äôm sick of reading about people who i would hate in real life. like, i‚Äôm only 50 pages into this book and the main character has already been fatphobic multiple times, anti-black towards a woman who was interested in her romantically, said that butch lesbians are ‚Äúas bad as any men‚Äù, and also transphobic. ??? why am i reading this??? it feels like the author has decided that the only way for a person to be flawed is for them to actively hold and espouse terrible political opinions, which is an idea i rebel against wholly and fully. to be flawed, to fuck up, to fail is so human. but it doesn‚Äôt have to equal holding structurally harmful views. not to be on my fanfiction agenda at all times but i could open up archiveofourown dot org and find over one hundred stories that are about people who mess up, hurt each other & miscommunicate and yet who aren‚Äôt total arseholes and, importantly, are treated with care by the narrative. by which i mean they are given the opportunity to grow, change and learn from their mistakes. they are flawed, yes, but they are also written as people who are trying to be good, trying to do better by the people they love.

another example of this is sorrow and bliss by meg mason, a truly incredible novel about how to live and love, to forgive and be forgiven. it‚Äôs not overly sentimental, not cloying or twee: real hurt is done by people to each other, and they have to search for how to move forwards. more than any other novel i‚Äôve read, it shows how it takes work to be in relation to one other. it feels real, unlike any of these other millennial novels about flawed people and difficult friendships. when reading these books i‚Äôm continually told that people understand one another, that they love and care about their friends despite being horrible to each another,¬† and sorry but i simply don‚Äôt believe it! i want to read books with a heart, with characters that fuck up and fail but who care about the people and the world around them, who change and are changed by each other. is that too much to ask for? i don‚Äôt think so.

in a total 180 from that book, i am also reading john reed‚Äôs ten days that shook the world, an incredible history of the october revolution. specifically, it‚Äôs a meticulous account of the events just preceding and following the seizure of state power by the bolsheviks. i think what this close focus accomplishes is a real emphasis on how chaotic and tumultuous those days were and how difficult it was for them to maintain control of the revolution. at the time, nobody thought the bolsheviks would last longer than 3 days in power, and reading this book you can see why: the forces stacked against them were so powerful. only with rigorous discipline and the might and dedication of the industrial proletariat could they fight back against the almost-instantaneous counter-revolution, make an alliance with the peasantry, navigate through the strikes of every government ministry and consolidate power. it really brings home what an achievement the revolution was‚Äînot only the victory in the class struggle but everything that came afterwards. it‚Äôs honestly mind-blowing when you think about it. as everyone reading this will know, i think lenin was that bitch but please allow me to reiterate: he really was that bitch!!!
